A spectacular destruction: How one email led to the downfall of a barrister who had it all

by PAUL BRACCHI

Last updated at 01:01 09 October 2007


An Oxford First, a brilliant radio career and newly qualified as a barrister, Bruce Hyman seemed to have all life's gifts - until a moment of utter madness put him behind bars and left his life in ruins...

Bruce Hyman woke up in a prison cell today. Inside, there is room for not much more than a single bed and a toilet.

Even so, it must seem like a sanctuary of sorts from the dangers which lurk outside his fortified door.

Anyone who says jails have gone "soft" has never been detained at Her Majesty's pleasure in places such as Bristol prison, where he was sent last month.

There, it was reported recently, drug-dealing inmates settle scores with razors and tins of corned beef swung in pillow cases.

It would be difficult to conceive of a more unlikely or incongruous "inmate" in such wretched surroundings than bespectacled, 49-year-old Hyman.

He has a First in French and philosophy from Oxford and, in the outside world, lives in a white-stuccoed Georgian mansion in Hampstead, North London, owns an Alpine ski chalet in Courchevel and wears Savile Row suits.

His father was a property developer and his mother a former magistrate; his brother, meanwhile, is a professor at Wadham College, Oxford.

Being wealthy, successful and locked up is one thing. Being the first barrister in 800 years of the English Bar to be sent down for attempting to pervert the course of justice is quite another.

Such was the fate of Bruce Anthony Hyman when he appeared in the dock last month. Someone who knows him described his slide into the metaphorical abyss as "Shakespearean".

Few would disagree that his ignominious fall has been spectacular and even tragic. Hyman worked from the prestigious Doughty Street Chambers, off Gray's Inn Road in central London.

Sir Mark Potter, president of the High Court's Family Division, and one of the country's most senior judges, was an admirer of Mr Hyman and stood by him during his trial.

Scroll down for more...

Hyman's celebrity friends from his other career as a theatre, radio and TV producer include Clive Anderson, Maureen Lipman, and Robbie Coltrane. Those are the eye-catching entries on his stellar CV.

Behind the professional face is also a loving husband, devoted father of four children, and, in the eyes of almost everyone who has had dealings with him, a deeply compassionate man.

Nursing a friend dying from cancer was one of his many acts of kindness. "He couldn't have done more for him," said an old colleague.

More than 20 people, including Sir Mark Potter, submitted glowing character references to the court where Hyman was being tried.

To no avail. He was jailed for 12 months for "appalling professional misconduct" which could have resulted in an innocent man losing his liberty - and which has now ended in Bruce Hyman losing much, much more.

He can no longer practise law and his chances of working as a TV producer again must also be in doubt. His wife Sarah is a writer, but it is her husband who is believed to have been the main breadwinner.

What the future now holds for this family of six and their elegant home must also be uncertain.

As his close friend and colleague Clive Anderson, himself a former barrister, told the Mail: "He had a lovely house, a beautiful wife and children, many friends, and it's all come crashing down."

The precise moment Bruce Hyman's life began to unravel is captured on CCTV footage. It was 12.52pm on September 22 last year when he sent an email from an electrical store, which happened to have internet access, in London's Tottenham Court Road to the former husband of a woman he was representing in a child custody battle.

It purported to be from the campaign group Families Need Fathers (and carried the FNF logo) documenting a Court of Appeal precedent which appeared to bolster the man's case.

Thinking it genuine, the man in question - Simon Eades, a former Wall Street banker - presented it before the court during the divorce hearing. The moment he did so, Hyman - who was of course acting for the man's ex-wife - promptly stood up and suggested not only that the document was a forgery, but that Mr Eades, who was representing himself, might have been responsible.

Mr Eades recalled: "I cannot describe the feelings that went through me. To be accused of a serious crime was horrendous. I was frantic, panic-stricken, not to mention angry."

Scroll down for more...

As we know, it was indeed a forgery - but it had been Hyman himself who had taken a genuine document and changed key paragraphs.

Had Mr Eades not managed to trace the source of the email then he, not Bruce Hyman, might be behind bars today, such would have been the repercussions of the barrister's intemperate actions.

When Mr Eades was able to discover that the email had been sent from that particular shop in London, it was relatively simple to recover the CCTV footage from that day and establish that it was Mr Hyman who was behind it.

So, a distinguished - and unblemished - career undone by one catastrophic error of judgment. Why, in God's name, did Bruce Hyman do it?

He is the only person who can answer that question, but what the Mail has learned is that he had been struggling to cope with the stress of his hugely demanding new career, and had turned to alcohol and cocaine to escape from the depression that was threatening to engulf him.

Given Bruce Hyman's predicament, it is hard to imagine that he once produced the remake of The Hitchhiker's Guide To The Galaxy and scores of other plays and comedies, working alongside the likes of Anthony Minghella, Michael Frayn and David Mamet.

Stars of stage and screen attended dinner and garden parties at his £2 million-plus Hampstead home, where Hyman played the piano and where he and wife Sarah, both accomplished cooks, laid on eagerly anticipated spreads. There were skiing holidays and rented villas in France or Italy, with guests such as Rowan Atkinson and Griff Rhys Jones.

Hyman also had a wicked sense of humour. On one occasion, he sent a note, supposedly from Robert De Niro, to a rather pompous radio scriptwriter who had penned a "truly awful" play.

"'De Niro' praised the actor's work and suggested the two should get together to discuss a film adaption," recalled a friend. The note was signed: "Bob, from Tribeca" (a district of New York City).

But it was Hyman's "fundamental decency", say those who know him, which has made what he did so shocking and difficult to comprehend.

There was the time he drove a close friend from London to Coventry in the middle of the night - "Bruce was still in his pyjamas" - when the man's father died suddenly.

He also provided "financial and practical" help to another friend who had succumbed to mental illness, as well as offering unstinting support for a young scriptwriter, Debbie Barham, who lost her long fight with anorexia in 2003.

"He was like a surrogate dad to Debbie," said her father Peter. "He was an immensely caring man with whom Debbie felt at ease. She knew he never judged her and was never too busy to listen."

It is almost impossible to recognise the Hyman of old with the man in the CCTV footage on Tottenham Court Road.

The chain of events which culminated in that fateful trip began more than five years ago. Hyman had become gripped by the drama of the legal profession through making the Radio 4 legal discussion programme Unreliable Evidence, fronted by Clive Anderson. (Could there be a more ironic name for a show in the circumstances?)

A Who's Who of the legal establishment appeared on the programme. Afterwards, guests would be entertained at smart Chelsea restaurants or, more often, at Mark's Club, the elegant private dining club in Mayfair opened by Mark Birley, founder of Annabel's.

What no one knew was that the executive producer of Unreliable Evidence had begun retraining as a barrister himself.

Hyman had always been fascinated by the law. Working on the series and coming into contact with the legal profession rekindled ambitions he had once harboured to become a lawyer himself.

"I think Bruce wanted to make sure he could pass the exams before telling everybody about it," recalled Clive Anderson.

In fact, Hyman was called to the Bar in 2004 after completing his pupillage - or legal internship - at Blackstone Chambers. Shortly afterwards, a friend and former trusted colleague received a call "out of the blue" from him.

Karen Sanders Young, 45, was recently divorced and embroiled in a dispute with her ex-husband over access to their daughter. Hyman had heard about this through the grapevine. He was now a lawyer, he told her. Could he help?

"I was delighted," Miss Sanders Young said, speaking to the Mail at her cottage in Wiltshire. "It was fantastic having someone with that expertise to advise me. He was always there to bounce ideas off and was always coming up with ways of tackling difficult situations."

In July last year, Hyman offered to represent her formally. "I would be billed by his chambers but he said he would reimburse me out of his own pocket," she explained. "Only if I got costs awarded would he take the money he was due."

Miss Sanders Young had no reason to doubt him. After all, Hyman was the image of a successful lawyer. But it was just a front.

What she did not know - and perhaps even those closest to him did not realise - was that the punishing hours demanded of a barrister, as well as the obvious pressure of starting such a demanding career in his mid-40s - were taking their toll.

Hyman also continued to run a production company. "The pressure to strike a balance between his two careers may have contributed to his problems," explains Clive Anderson.

Either way, previously unreported evidence from a psychologist, presented to the judge at Bristol Crown Court last month, paints a harrowing picture of a man in crisis.

Hyman had started "developing symptoms of a depressive illness" when he became a barrister, and had subsequently turned to drink and drugs as an escape. He had also become increasingly "low, detached, agitated ... not eating properly."

Bruce Hyman was undoubtedly brilliant; but being a barrister required the kind of intellectual rigour, discipline and mental stamina which most people, not just someone coming to the job later in life, would have found highly taxing.

"He was not suited to being a barrister," concluded the medical expert bluntly.

Hyman, it emerges, had completed two six-month pupillages - but was not offered a permanent job at either.

It seems this dramatic decline in Hyman's state of mind contributed to his decision to send the fabricated email. Perhaps he was desperate to win the case on behalf of his old friend Karen - or perhaps it was symptomatic of the wider malaise in his life.

What we now know is that days after sending the email, Hyman resigned from the Bar. Was it remorse, or simply an acceptance that he wasn't cut out for the law?

Despite this, soon after, he still accompanied Karen Sanders Young for a hearing at Taunton Family Court in Somerset last September.

Why he continued with a charade which would have such devastating consequences only he can say - but it's certain that his actions had a dramatic fallout for his client.

"I am incredibly grateful for the support Bruce gave to me and the wonderful legal help he gave me up until the day he tried to pull that stunt," said Miss Sanders Young.

"Even when I heard the rumours he had been arrested, I didn't believe them. How wrong I was. I was already close to a nervous breakdown when Bruce committed this act of insanity.

"I have not heard a word from him since that day. His lawyer made a public apology in court last month, but he has never said sorry to me in person."

Hyman pleaded guilty to attempting to pervert the course of justice when he appeared at Bristol Crown Court. His wife of 11 years, Sarah Hyman, told how her husband had acted "completely out of character" and had broken down when he finally confessed what he had done.

"He was sobbing, clutching his hair, pacing the room, saying 'Please don't leave me,'" she recalled.

But despite his previous good character and apparent remorse, a custodial sentence was handed down. As Hyman was led away, he mouthed "I love you" to his wife.

She and his friends, including Maureen Lipman, stand by him. "Bruce was a great support after my husband died," Miss Lipman told the Mail. "He is a dignified and decent man whom I support in every conceivable way.

"I would trust Bruce Hyman with my life and my children's lives. He pleaded guilty but there were extenuating circumstances."

The judge acknowledged Hyman "had committed the offence in exceptional circumstances" but he said the punishment must reflect the seriousness of the crime. Although he was given a 12-month sentence, he will be released on parole after six months, and is expected to be transferred shortly to an open prison.

For the moment, though, his world consists mostly of a 10ft by 6ft space in an overcrowded prison.

Perhaps his real sentence, however, will only begin when he is freed.

"Bruce Hyman has destroyed his career at the Bar and damaged, probably beyond repair, his prospects in his previous career as a producer of radio programmes, one that is based largely on trust," his own barrister said in mitigation.

Of course, what he did was wrong, but many might think he has paid a very high price indeed for one catastrophic error of judgment.
